summary: Email correspondence between defense attorney Laura Menninger and prosecutors regarding discovery issues in the US v. Maxwell case, focusing on problems accessing and viewing thousands of photos and videos, discrepancies in the number of 'highly confidential' images, and disputes over access to nude/sexualized images that are not child pornography.

persons.context: Partner at Haddon, Morgan & Foreman representing Ghislaine Maxwell; raising multiple discovery deficiencies regarding photo and video evidence, requesting access to 'highly confidential' materials.

events.title: Evidence Review Meeting
events.description: Meeting in NY where defense attorney reviewed evidence including 'highly confidential' hard drives.

events.title: FBI Report on Epstein Device Images
events.description: FBI report indicating approximately 33,747 'highly confidential' images and 895 HC videos identified from digital review of CART-processed evidence from Epstein's devices.

locations: 500 Pearl (likely courthouse or government office in NY)
keyFacts: Prosecution initially told defense there were approximately 2,100 'nude' or highly confidential images from Epstein's devices, but an FBI report indicated approximately 33,747 HC images and 895 HC videos - a major discrepancy.

Defense requested access to all 'highly confidential' material minus child pornography, arguing that reviewing adult nudity only in government offices imposes extraordinary costs and impedes defense preparation.
Thousands of photo files provided in discovery were unreadable by defense due to file format issues, corrupt spreadsheets, and lack of appropriate viewers.

Prosecution defined 'Highly Confidential' as containing 'nude, partially-nude, or otherwise sexualized images, videos, or other depictions of individuals' and was working to de-designate images not depicting genitals, breasts, or buttocks.
Evidence included images extracted from disks in black binders (approximately 40,000 images with 3,400 deemed HC) and from Epstein's devices searched pursuant to warrant.
